member.summary: If set the subscription will prefer if possible to dispatch only to a single of the connected clients. If however the buffer limits are reached on that client it will begin sending to other clients.

member.name: M:EventStore.ClientAPI.PersistentSubscriptionSettingsBuilder.StartFromBeginning
member.summary: Sets that the subscription should start from the beginning of the stream.

member.name: M:EventStore.ClientAPI.PersistentSubscriptionSettingsBuilder.StartFrom(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets that the subscription should start from a specified location of the stream.

member.name: M:EventStore.ClientAPI.PersistentSubscriptionSettingsBuilder.WithMessageTimeoutOf(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Sets the timeout for a message (will be retried if an ack is not received within this timespan)

member.name: M:EventStore.ClientAPI.PersistentSubscriptionSettingsBuilder.CheckPointAfter(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Sets that the backend should try to checkpoint the subscription after some period of time. Note that if the increment of the ceheckpoint would be below the minimum the stream will not be checkpointed at this time.
member.remarks: It is important to tweak checkpointing for high performance streams as they cause writes to happen back in the system. There is a trade off between the number of writes that can happen in varying failure scenarios and the frequency of writing out the checkpoints within the system. Normally settings such as once per second with a minimum of 5-10 messages and a high max to checkpoint should be a good compromise for most streams though you may want to change this if you for instance are doing hundreds of messages/second through the subscription.
member.param: The amount of time to try checkpointing after

member.name: M:EventStore.ClientAPI.PersistentSubscriptionSettingsBuilder.MinimumCheckPointCountOf(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the minimum checkpoint count. The subscription will not increment a checkpoint below this value eg if there is one item to checkpoint and it is set to five it will not checkpoint
member.remarks: It is important to tweak checkpointing for high performance streams as they cause writes to happen back in the system. There is a trade off between the number of writes that can happen in varying failure scenarios and the frequency of writing out the checkpoints within the system. Normally settings such as once per second with a minimum of 5-10 messages and a high max to checkpoint should be a good compromise for most streams though you may want to change this if you for instance are doing hundreds of messages/second through the subscription.
member.param: The minimum count to checkpoint

member.name: M:EventStore.ClientAPI.PersistentSubscriptionSettingsBuilder.MaximumCheckPointCountOf(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the largest increment the subscription will checkpoint. If this value is reached the subscription will immediately write a checkpoint. As such this value should normally be reasonably large so as not to cause too many writes to occur in the subscription
member.remarks: It is important to tweak checkpointing for high performance streams as they cause writes to happen back in the system. There is a trade off between the number of writes that can happen in varying failure scenarios and the frequency of writing out the checkpoints within the system. Normally settings such as once per second with a minimum of 5-10 messages and a high max to checkpoint should be a good compromise for most streams though you may want to change this if you for instance are doing hundreds of messages/second through the subscription.
member.param: The maximum count to checkpoint

member.name: M:EventStore.ClientAPI.PersistentSubscriptionSettingsBuilder.WithMaxRetriesOf(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the number of times a message should be retried before being considered a bad message

member.name: M:EventStore.ClientAPI.PersistentSubscriptionSettingsBuilder.WithLiveBufferSizeOf(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the size of the live buffer for the subscription. This is the buffer used to cache messages while sending messages as they happen. The count is in terms of the number of messages to cache.

member.name: M:EventStore.ClientAPI.DnsClusterSettingsBuilder.SetClusterGossipPort(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Sets the well-known port on which the cluster gossip is taking place.
If you are using the commercial edition of Event Store HA, with Manager nodes in place, this should be the port number of the External HTTP port on which the managers are running.
If you are using the open source edition of Event Store HA, this should be the External HTTP port that the nodes are running on. If you cannot use a well-known port for this across all nodes, you can instead use gossip seed discovery and set the of some seed nodes instead.
member.param: The cluster gossip port.

member.name: T:EventStore.ClientAPI.EventStoreNodeConnection
member.summary: Maintains a full duplex connection to the EventStore
member.remarks:
An operates quite differently than say a . Normally when using an you want to keep the connection open for a much longer of time than when you use a SqlConnection. If you prefer the usage pattern of using(new Connection()) .. then you would likely want to create a FlyWeight on top of the .
Another difference is that with the all operations are handled in a full async manner (even if you call the synchronous behaviors). Many threads can use an at the same time or a single thread can make many asynchronous requests. To get the most performance out of the connection it is generally recommended to use it in this way.

member.name: M:EventStore.ClientAPI.IEventStoreConnection.AppendToStreamAsync(System.String,System.Int32,EventStore.ClientAPI.EventData[])
member.summary: Appends Events asynchronously to a stream.
member.remarks:
When appending events to a stream the choice can make a very large difference in the observed behavior. For example, if no stream exists and ExpectedVersion.Any is used, a new stream will be implicitly created when appending.
There are also differences in idempotency between different types of calls. If you specify an ExpectedVersion aside from ExpectedVersion.Any the Event Store will give you an idempotency guarantee. If using ExpectedVersion.Any the Event Store will do its best to provide idempotency but does not guarantee idempotency
member.param: The name of the stream to append events to
The of the stream to append to
The events to append to the stream

member.summary:
Subscribes to a single event stream. Existing events from lastCheckpoint onwards are read from the stream and presented to the user of as if they had been pushed.
Once the end of the stream is read the subscription is transparently (to the user) switched to push new events as they are written.
The action liveProcessingStarted is called when the switches from the reading phase to the live subscription phase.
member.param: The stream to subscribe to

The event number from which to start.
To receive all events in the stream, use . If events have already been received and resubscription from the same point is desired, use the event number of the last event processed which appeared on the subscription.
NOTE: Using here will result in missing the first event in the stream.
Whether to resolve Link events automatically
An action invoked when an event is received over the subscription
An action invoked when the subscription switches to newly-pushed events
An action invoked if the subscription is dropped
User credentials to use for the operation
The batch size to use during the read phase

member.summary: Asynchronously subscribes to all events in the Event Store. New events written to the stream while the subscription is active will be pushed to the client.

An action invoked when a new event is received over the subscription

member.summary: Subscribes a persistent subscription (competing consumer) to the event store
member.param: The subscription group to connect to
The stream to subscribe to
An action invoked when an event appears
An action invoked if the subscription is dropped
User credentials to use for the operation
The buffer size to use for the persistent subscription
Whether the subscription should automatically acknowledge messages processed. If not set the receiver is required to explicitly acknowledge messages through the subscription.
member.remarks: This will connect you to a persistent subscription group for a stream. The subscription group must first be created with CreatePersistentSubscriptionGroup many connections can connect to the same group and they will be treated as competing consumers within the group. If one connection dies work will be balanced across the rest of the consumers in the group. If you attempt to connect to a group that does not exist you will be given an exception.

member.summary:

member.name: T:EventStore.ClientAPI.ExpectedVersion
member.summary: Constants used for expected version control
member.remarks:
The use of expected version can be a bit tricky especially when discussing idempotency assurances given by the event store.
There are four possible values that can be used for the passing of an expected version.
ExpectedVersion.Any (-2) says that you should not conflict with anything. ExpectedVersion.NoStream (-1) says that the stream should not exist when doing your write. ExpectedVersion.EmptyStream (0) says the stream should exist but be empty when doing the write.
Any other value states that the last event written to the stream should have a sequence number matching your expected value.
The Event Store will assure idempotency for all operations using any value in ExpectedVersion except for ExpectedVersion.Any. When using ExpectedVersion.Any the Event Store will do its best to assure idempotency but will not guarantee idempotency.

member.name: F:EventStore.ClientAPI.ExpectedVersion.Any
member.summary: This write should not conflict with anything and should always succeed.

member.name: F:EventStore.ClientAPI.ExpectedVersion.NoStream
member.summary: The stream being written to should not yet exist. If it does exist treat that as a concurrency problem.

member.name: F:EventStore.ClientAPI.ExpectedVersion.EmptyStream
member.summary: The stream should exist and should be empty. If it does not exist or is not empty treat that as a concurrency problem.
